pr_title: clarify distinction between file names and class names

timeline.bodyText:
This locates a class file in a class path. Not in a class path entry. This FixedSizeClassPathRepository operates on a class path.
Do you see this description is inaccurate?
timeline.author: suztomo
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -52,14 +52,15 @@ * *

While class name and class file name are the same in most cases, sometimes classes are not * placed in the root of a JAR file to support a framework-specific JAR structure. For example, - * Spring Boot Gradle Java plugin places class files under "BOOT-INF/classes". To load such + * the Spring Boot Gradle Java plugin places class files under "BOOT-INF/classes". To load such * classes by class name, this mapping keeps track of the special location once they are loaded. * *

    *
  • Key: class name (value from {@link JavaClass#getClassName()}) which has a special class * file name different from its class name. Example: {@code com.google.Foo} *
  • Value: the special class file name as in {@link JavaClass#getFileName()}, a path that - * locates a class file in a class path. Example: {@code BOOT-INF.classes.com.google.Foo} + * locates a class file in a class path entry.

replies.bodyText: A class file name such as BOOT-INF.classes.com.google.Foo does not tell us which jar the file is in. It only tells us where in this jar the file will be. Or am I misunderstanding the special class file name?
replies.author: elharo

replies.bodyText:
A class file name such as BOOT-INF.classes.com.google.Foo does not tell us which jar the file is in

Correct. No specific JAR file. That's why this is a path to locate a class file in a class path, not a JAR file.
replies.author: suztomo

replies.bodyText: I think I see where you're coming from, but I don't think as written this is correct. For instance, there can be multiple files with the same name in the class path. There can be only one of these in a class path entry. Perhaps we need to get rid of the notion of this as "locating" something. That's not what it does.
replies.author: elharo

timeline.bodyText: This is nice. Placing getOrDefault here is simplifying other places.
timeline.author: suztomo

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change * A few tools relocate classes into different directories within the JAR and use a special *

A few tools relocate classes into different directories within the JAR and use a special I like the clear explanation of the difference.
timeline.author: suztomo
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -48,18 +48,23 @@ private final Cache loadedClass; /** - * Mapping from class names to special class file locations. + * Mapping from class names to file names. * - *

While class name and class file name are the same in most cases, sometimes classes are not - * placed in the root of a JAR file to support a framework-specific JAR structure. For example, - * Spring Boot Gradle Java plugin places class files under "BOOT-INF/classes". To load such - * classes by class name, this mapping keeps track of the special location once they are loaded. + *

Class names are the fully package qualified names found in Java source code such as + * {@code com.google.Foo}. The byte code of this class is normally found in a JAR at the path + * com/google/Foo.class. In this case {@code com.google.Foo} is also the file name. + * + * A few tools relocate classes into different directories within the JAR and use a special
